I'd be happy to help you understand the potential connection between Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS), nausea, and stomach pain. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a group of genetic disorders that affect the body's connective tissue, which provides support and structure to various organs and systems throughout the body. One of the most common symptoms of EDS is joint hypermobility, but individuals with EDS may also experience other signs such as skin hyperextensibility, bruising easily, and poor wound healing. Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) is a type of autonomic nervous system disorder that is often associated with EDS. POTS occurs when the body has difficulty regulating heart rate and blood pressure during changes in posture, leading to rapid heartbeat, dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting spells upon standing. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and are typically triggered by sudden changes in position or exercise. Nausea and abdominal pain are two additional symptoms that people with EDS and/or POTS may experience. These gastrointestinal issues could result from several factors related to EDS and/or POTS, including: Gastric motility disturbances: EDS and POTS might impair the normal functioning of the digestive system, causing food to move too quickly or slowly through the stomach and small intestine. This could lead to nausea, bloating, cramping, diarrhea, or constipation. Hormonal imbalances: The autonomic nervous system plays a crucial role in regulating hormone secretion and metabolism. Disruptions in autonomic function caused by EDS and/or POTS might affect hormones like cortisol, insulin, and ghrelin, contributing to symptoms like nausea, fatigue, and weight changes. Maldigestion and malabsorption: Some individuals with EDS and/or POTS have trouble breaking down certain nutrients due to

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a group of genetic disorders that affect the connective tissues in the body. One common symptom of EDS is Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS), which is a condition characterized by an abnormal increase in heart rate upon standing up. Nausea and stomach pain can be associated with EDS and POTS, although they are not specific to these conditions and can have various other causes. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of your symptoms. Stomach pain and nausea can be caused by gastrointestinal dysmotility, which is commonly seen in individuals with EDS and POTS. Dysmotility refers to abnormal movement of the digestive tract, leading to symptoms such as bloating, abdominal pain, and nausea. Other potential causes of stomach pain and nausea in individuals with EDS and POTS include: 1. Gastroparesis: It is a condition where the stomach muscles do not function properly, leading to delayed emptying of the stomach contents. This can cause symptoms like early satiety, bloating, and nausea. 2. Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO): EDS and POTS patients may have an increased risk of SIBO, which occurs when there is an overgrowth of bacteria in the small intestine. This can result in symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. 3. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): EDS and POTS can also contribute to the development of GERD, a condition where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn, regurgitation, and nausea. Managing stomach pain and nausea in individuals with EDS and POTS may involve a multidisciplinary approach, including lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, medications, and physical therapy. It is crucial to work with healthcare professionals who are knowledgeable about these conditions to develop an individualized treatment plan.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a group of genetic disorders that affect the body's connective tissue, which provides support to various organs and structures throughout the body, including the heart, blood vessels, joints, skin, and digestive system. Some individuals with EDS may experience symptoms related to autonomic dysfunction, such as postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS), nausea, and stomach pain. Here's what you need to know: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS): Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) is a condition in which an individual experiences a rapid heart rate upon standing or changing positions, often accompanied by symptoms like lightheadedness, fainting, fatigue, brain fog, and shortness of breath. POTS can occur due to autonomic nervous system dysfunction, which is commonly seen in individuals with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). The exact mechanisms underlying POTS in EDS are not fully understood; however, several theories suggest that it could be related to problems within the autonomic nervous system, including abnormalities in neuronal functioning, neurotransmitter imbalances, and impaired baroreceptor functioning. Nausea and Stomach Pain: Individuals with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) may also experience gastrointestinal symptoms, including nausea and stomach pain, which can vary in severity and frequency depending on the specific type of EDS they have. These gastrointestinal issues might result from difficulties in the body's ability to process nutrients, poor gut motility, or increased sensitivity to certain foods. In some cases, gastroparesis (delayed emptying of food from the stomach into the small intestine) has been observed in people with EDS. In conclusion, if you suspect you or someone you know may have Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) and are experiencing symptoms such as POTS, nausea, and stomach pain, consult your doctor for proper evaluation and diagnosis. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissues in the body. POTS, or Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome, is a condition that causes symptoms such as lightheadedness and rapid heartbeat upon standing. Nausea and stomach pain can also be part of the EDS POTS symptoms. Some tips for managing symptoms include staying hydrated, pacing activities, using compression stockings, and working with a physical therapist or occupational therapist. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

The Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is an autoimmune disease of the connective tissue that results in muscle weakness, joint stiffness, tenderness and fatigue throughout one's body. This debilitating condition results from a genetic defect on the gene encoding collagen type I, which makes up 90% of all connective tissues, as well as another gene that produces collagen type III, or elastin.\r POTS means postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, which is a form of autonomic nervous system dysfunction that can cause dizziness, syncope, fainting spells and shortness of breath. \r Symptoms include fatigue, loss of energy, confusion, palpitations and heart palpitations. There may be other symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weight gain and constipation.\r People with this disorder often feel lightheaded and have difficulty walking for long periods of time due to the effects of low blood pressure. They also experience back pain that becomes worse with standing. Other symptoms associated with this disorder include muscle spasms, numbness, tingling, prickly sensations, skin rashes, hair loss and darkening of the nails.\r Nausea and vomiting are both symptoms that occur frequently during POTS episodes. Gastrointestinal distress may also contribute to some cases of POTS because it causes gastrointestinal discomfort. \r If you suspect you may have POTS, you should discuss your symptoms with your physician who will likely order additional tests to determine if the diagnosis is correct. If the test shows that you do indeed have POTS, you may need medication treatments as well. However, if the symptoms resolve on their own without treatment, then the disease may simply be a symptom of underlying diseases such as asthma, diabetes and cardiovascular conditions. In some instances, the underlying causes may not yet be known. \r More information: http://www.ehleros.com/newsletter_pressrelease.asp?cid=1187\u0026bfrlsef&catid=6

Pain and gastrointestinal dysfunction are significant associations with psychiatric disorders in patients with Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and hypermobility spectrum disorders: a retrospective study , , , , , & , –() In this retrospective study, we investigate the frequency and types of psychiatric disorders and their relationship to systemic manifestations in a cohort of 391 Ehlers–Danlos syndromes (EDS) and hypermobility spectrum disorder (HSD) patients based on the current 2017 International Classification of EDS diagnostic criteria. A detailed, systematic retrospective chart review was undertaken for patients assessed for HSD or EDS at two Canadian health centres. Patients were diagnosed according to the Villefranche criteria and reclassified for this study according to the 2017 International Classification of EDS. Data validation and statistical analyses were conducted. Psychiatric disorders were very common, with 49.4% of the total cohort affected; 28.9% reported multiple psychiatric diagnoses. Mood (34.5%) and somatoform (28.6%) disorders were most common. Interestingly, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was significantly enriched in the HSD, but not EDS cohort ( = 0.0002, 95% CI 3.48–9.00) compared to the general population. There were no differences in the systemic associations with having psychiatric manifestations in the HSD compared to the EDS subsets. Muscle/body pain (OR 1.99) and gastrointestinal dysfunction (OR 2.07) were significantly associated with having mood disorders, and gastrointestinal dysfunction (OR 2.61) and nerve-related pain (OR 3.27) were associated with having somatoform disorders across the cohort. The common systemic associations with the presence of psychiatric manifestations in both HSD and EDS reaffirm that the conditions should be treated as a spectrum rather than as wholly separate entities, particularly with respect to psychiatric management. EDS and HSD patients share common psychiatric presentations, though ADHD is more common with HSD. This is a preview of subscription content, to check access. If you were unable to find an answer that was correct for your question, please contact our Customer Care Center at 800-838-2277 or email us at support@heartsandscholar.com\r \r Health care professionals have been told by their patients that if they do not see any improvement after several weeks, it is probably a sign that something is wrong. This is because symptoms can develop rapidly in some people who go through very severe illness. For example, someone with multiple sclerosis will start seeing a wide range of changes within 3-6 months of diagnosis, but may not show signs of serious illness until a year later.\r In general, it takes only a few days for many people to become severely ill. Some people experience symptoms that last a week or more. In fact, some people actually have much longer illness than this.\r A person may suddenly begin showing all kinds of bizarre behavior, including eating strange foods, falling down stairs, getting lost on the street, jumping from moving cars, experiencing extreme panic attacks, and so on. The doctor should be alert to these behaviors, as well as the obvious physical problems such as vomiting, loss of appetite, fatigue, and dizziness. Symptoms of Ehlers Danlos syndrome can come on suddenly, often without warning, and then disappear after a time. They usually appear gradually over the course of weeks to months, and can range from mild discomfort, such as occasional stomach aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramping, or headaches, to severe fatigue, blurred vision, numbness/tingling in one side of the body, difficulty breathing, seizures, coma, and death.\r People with Ehlers Danlos syndrome cannot normally swallow food whole. It's just too painful. So what happens when patients lose control of their bowels? One explanation is that fluids accumulate inside their bodies. When you drink, urine collects around the edges of your stomach. When you vomit, large amounts of liquid fall out onto the floor. This fluid contains many minerals (such as calcium, potassium and magnesium) which can cause kidney stones. \r It isn't known exactly how water gets into the intestines during vomiting; the fluid accumulates in the small intestine. However, there has been speculation that dehydration causes the accumulation of water in the gastrointestinal tract. There are two types of damage caused by

Mayo Clinic Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences Mayo Clinic School of Continuous Professional Development Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome and chronic fatigue in adolescents: Working toward recovery Chronic fatigue is common and often multifactorial in adolescents. In some patients, fatigue is due to a concurrent medical condition, inadequate sleep habits or coexisting psychological challenges. Occasionally, however, the fatigue persists in the absence of identifiable medical conditions. Many teens who experience chronic fatigue have additional symptoms, including tachycardia, dizziness, headaches, nausea and abdominal pain, that suggest the presence of some form of autonomic dysfunction. Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) is one type of autonomic dysfunction. Specific definitions vary, but generally include chronic fatigue and two key components: Excessive postural tachycardia (more than 40 beats a minute) with supine to upright positioning on a tilt table In addition to these signs and symptoms, adolescents with POTS often also experience depression and anxiety. According to , a pediatric physiatrist at Mayo Clinic Children's Center in Minnesota, the social and economic consequences related to POTS are significant. "Adolescent patients diagnosed with POTS may experience decreased school attendance, withdrawal from extracurricular activities, decreased academic performance and truancy," notes Dr. Driscoll. "And, as patients have multiple consultations while seeking a diagnosis and treatment, this condition can also have a significant financial impact on families." While research continues to explore the pathophysiology of this condition, it's important to note that effective treatment is available for these patients. Dr. Driscoll advises that once the medical evaluation is complete, providers should encourage patients and their families to move beyond the search for medical diagnoses and focus on recovery. "Education and motivating patients to incorporate new healthy-living practices into their lives can help remediate POTS symptoms and reduce the negative impact of POTS and chronic fatigue in adolescents," says Dr. Driscoll. In a recent article published in Current Problems in Pediatric and Adolescent Health Care, Dr. Driscoll and colleagues provide an overview about POTS and chronic fatigue, reviewing the relevant medical and psychological literature, and drawing upon the authors' practice experiences. Below are a few highlights from this review article, focusing on recovery strategies. As they struggle to find help for a condition that is not yet well-understood, many patients with POTS and their parents experience feelings of isolation and lack of social support. Education focusing on self-management and fostering social support is helpful. Individual and group education sessions that involve both patients and their families can encourage social interaction and lessen the feelings of isolation. Sessions should encourage a systematic approach to comprehensive lifestyle changes required for managing this condition. Patients with POTS can experience a wide range of symptoms that no single medication or treatment can relieve. Treatment plans at Mayo Clinic typically use multidisciplinary care teams that may include specialists in general pediatrics, neurology, physical medicine and rehabilitation, sleep medicine, pulmonology, cardiology, infectious disease, psychology, psychiatry, and others as needed. Improvement in sleep hygiene, aerobic exercise and strength training, and cognitive behavioral

One sign of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is having joints that can extend past the normal range of motion. See more The human body is made up of many kinds of tissue that serve important daily functions. Tissues hold the body together, protect the body's insides, enable movement and carry electrical messages from the brain to the rest of the body. Everything the body does depends on its tissues. So what happens when connective tissues, including bones and inner layers of skin, don't work the way they should? Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, or EDS, is an inherited genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissues and prevents the body from functioning in the way that it should. Symptoms of EDS include: Joints that move beyond the normal range of motion, which can lead to dislocations and chronic pain Extremely delicate skin that is susceptible to injury Overly stretchy skin, which makes the skin vulnerable to damage and exposes a person's internal organs to harm EDS abnormalities such as these are caused by faulty collagen, which is the substance that gives strength and elasticity to connective tissues in the skin, joints and blood vessel walls [source: ]. The six main types of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome each have their own specific symptoms. The severity of these symptoms varies on a case-by-case basis, sometimes affecting the patient in such a minor way that EDS goes undiagnosed, and sometimes causing severe mobility issues. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is rare, and patients diagnosed with EDS should remain under a doctor's care in order to address their specific symptoms. If you or someone you know has been diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, you might be wondering what the symptoms of EDS are and how it is treated. You also might be worried about passing it on to your children. Keep reading to find out what you need to know. Although all forms of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome share certain symptoms, such as muscle fatigue and stretchy skin, the six distinct types of EDS each present specific symptoms. Three of these types are extremely rare. The most common forms of EDS are hypermobility, classical EDS and vascular EDS. , which affects 1 in 10,000 to 15,000 people, causes looseness in both large and small joints. Dislocations are common, and patients often experience pain in their joints and limbs [source: ]. affects 1 in 20,000 to 40,000 people, and it's marked by skin hyperextensibility (stretchiness), scars and wounds that don't heal properly, fatty and noncancerous growths, and delicate skin tissue that is vulnerable to bruising [source: ]. has been reported in an estimated 1 in 250,000 people. This type is considered highly serious because of the risk of major organs or blood vessels rupturing. People with vascular EDS have very thin and fragile skin, which is often so translucent that veins can be seen through it [source: ]. Easy bruising is common. High risk factors associated with vascular EDS often result in a life expectancy of about 50 years [source: ]. The other three forms of EDS are rare, having been reported in fewer than 100 cases worldwide. , which

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of inherited disorders that affect your connective tissues — primarily your skin, joints and blood vessel walls. Connective tissue is a complex mixture of proteins and other substances that provide strength and elasticity to the underlying structures in your body. People who have Ehlers-Danlos syndrome usually have overly flexible joints and stretchy, fragile skin. This can become a problem if you have a wound that requires stitches, because the skin often isn't strong enough to hold them. A more severe form of the disorder, called vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, can cause the walls of your blood vessels, intestines or uterus to rupture. Because vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can have serious potential complications in pregnancy, you may want to talk to a genetic counselor before starting a family. There are many different types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, but the most common signs and symptoms include: Because the connective tissue that holds joints together is looser, your joints can move far past the normal range of motion. Joint pain and dislocations are common. Weakened connective tissue allows your skin to stretch much more than usual. You may be able to pull a pinch of skin up away from your flesh, but it will snap right back into place when you let go. Your skin might also feel exceptionally soft and velvety. Damaged skin often doesn't heal well. For example, the stitches used to close a wound often will tear out and leave a gaping scar. These scars may look thin and crinkly. Symptom severity can vary from person to person and depends on the specific type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome that you have. The most common type is called hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. People who have vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome often share distinctive facial features of a thin nose, thin upper lip, small earlobes and prominent eyes. They also have thin, translucent skin that bruises very easily. In fair-skinned people, the underlying blood vessels are very visible through the skin. Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can weaken your heart's largest artery (aorta), as well as the arteries to other regions of your body. A rupture of any of these larger blood vessels can be fatal. The vascular type can also weaken the walls of the uterus or large intestines — which also may rupture. Different types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are associated with a variety of genetic causes, some of which are inherited and passed on from parent to child. If you have the most common form, hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, there's a 50% chance that you'll pass on the gene to each of your children. Complications depend on the types of signs and symptoms you have. For example, overly flexible joints can result in joint dislocations and early-onset arthritis. Fragile skin may develop prominent scarring. People who have vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are at risk of often fatal ruptures of major blood vessels. Some organs, such as the uterus and intestines, also may rupture. Pregnancy can increase the risk of a rupture in the uterus. Yes! This is an uncommon but serious condition which affects more than 1 in 250 people around the world. It causes severe vomiting of food or liquids after eating too much protein intake due either naturally occurring toxins like bile acids or excess sugar consumption by your diet. Symptoms include abdominal pains (often with cramping) that last for at least 4 hours followed quickly upon returning from consuming something else - such as coffee, pizza crusts etc..
